The district will update the phase for the weeks of Sept. 28 and Oct. 5 on Friday, Sept. 18. This change does not impact HCS at Home students.

post_text:
The Book with No Pictures by BJ Novak is the #HCSBookoftheWeek nominated by Soddy Elementary. You might think a book with no pictures seems boring and serious. Except, here's how books work. Everything written on the page has to be said by the person reading it aloud. Even if the words say, BLORK or BLUURF, it still must be read aloud. Even if the words are a preposterous song about eating ants for breakfast or just a list of astonishingly goofy sounds like BLAGGITY BLAGGITY and GLIBBITY GLOBBITY.

"Elementary school kiddos love this book because of the rich, creative word choices," said Lindsay Prater, librarian at Soddy Elementary. "This book makes any kid laugh out loud. It's an amazing read aloud."
text:
The Book with No Pictures by BJ Novak is the #HCSBookoftheWeek nominated by Soddy Elementary. You might think a book with no pictures seems boring and serious. Except, here's how books work. Everything written on the page has to be said by the person reading it aloud. Even if the words say, BLORK or BLUURF, it still must be read aloud. Even if the words are a preposterous song about eating ants for breakfast or just a list of astonishingly goofy sounds like BLAGGITY BLAGGITY and GLIBBITY GLOBBITY.

"Elementary school kiddos love this book because of the rich, creative word choices," said Lindsay Prater, librarian at Soddy Elementary. "This book makes any kid laugh out loud. It's an amazing read aloud."

#WholeChildWednesday September is Suicide Prevention Awareness Month. This week’ we’re joined by Rachel Gearinger, Southeast Regional Director of the Tennessee Suicide Prevention Network. Tune in as Rachel shares about tips and warning signs to look for with your student.

For additional resources, visit the TSPN online: www.tspn.org or www.facebook.com/TSPNorg. If you or a school-aged youth in your life is struggling with thoughts of suicide, call the Mobile Crisis Line at (866) 791-9225

post_text:
Knowing how many children live in a community will provide the foundation for important policy and planning decisions over the next 10 years. That’s why it is so important to count everyone living in your home. Be sure to count children of relatives, friends or other people who live and sleep in your home most of the time.

Census results can affect funding for many programs aimed at school-age children such as the school lunch program, Head Start Programs, and teacher training funding. Census data also helps secure funds for things like roads, hospitals, and fire stations.

The deadline to complete the 2020 Census is Sept. 30. If you haven't yet, please take a minute to take the census: https://2020census.gov/en/ways-to-respond.html

post_text:
Hamilton County Schools will remain in Phase 3 for Sept. 14-25 due to active case numbers remaining in Phase 3. We will continue to evaluate every two weeks and share an update on the phase on Friday, Sept. 18.

Tuesday, Sept. 22, will likely be a system-wide remote learning day for high school ACT and enhanced cleaning of elementary and middle schools. We will confirm this on Tuesday, Sept. 8, when we return from the Labor Day holiday.

We appreciate your continued grace and patience as we work through this unprecedented time. We are grateful for the cooperation and support of our community.

To view today's phase tracker, visit www.hcde.org/reentryplan

post_text:
Beginning Tuesday, Sept. 8, all students will be able to eat free. Here are a few details:

-Students that normally pay reduced or full-pay prices will no longer be charged for breakfast or lunch.
-Each student is permitted one breakfast and one lunch per day. A la carte items are not included.
-Pickup meals will continue to be provided each week, and all of these meals will be provided free to students.
-These meals are paid for by a USDA program.

post_text:
The War That Saved My Life by Kimberly Brubaker Bradley is the #HCSBookoftheWeek nominated by Spring Creek Elementary. Ten-year-old Ada has never left her one-room apartment. Her mother is too humiliated by Ada's twisted foot to let her outside. So when her little brother Jamie is shipped out of London to escape the war, Ada doesn't waste a minute—she sneaks out to join him. So begins a new adventure for Ada, and for Susan Smith, the woman who is forced to take in the two kids. As Ada teaches herself to ride a pony, learns to read, and watches for German spies, she begins to trust Susan, and Susan begins to love Ada and Jamie. In the end, will their bond be enough to hold them together through wartime, or will Ada and her brother be sent back to their mother?

"Students root for this character and can't wait to read more," said Jeannette Yahn, librarian at Spring Creek Elementary. "Our 4th and 5th graders LOVE this book!"

Today Hamilton County Schools held a Swearing-In Ceremony for our newly elected and re-elected school board members. Joe Wingate, District 7 and board chairman, and Tiffanie Robinson, District 4, are returning board members. Marco Perez will be the new board representative for District 2.

We thank you for your service over the next four years!

*Note: Rhonda Thurman, District 1, was also re-elected but did not attend the ceremony. She was sworn in at a prior date.

post_text:
This is a reminder for families participating in the HCS at Home program that attendance is still required even though students are learning remotely.

Student attendance is taken daily. When students are scheduled to be in a live class session, they must arrive no later than five (5) minutes after the start time to be counted as “present” for that class.

For classes not meeting in live, real-time class session on a particular day, a student’s attendance may be counted by logging into the learning management system (CANVAS or Class Dojo), submitting an assignment, responding to the daily check-in task or question, or working in a small group. #HCSatHome

post_text:
It's time for our first #HCSBookoftheWeek for the 2020-2021 school year!

The Word Collector by Peter H. Reynolds is this week's #HCSBookoftheWeek nominated by North Hamilton County Elementary. Some people collect stamps. Some people collect coins. Some people collect art. And Jerome? He collected words. In this extraordinary new tale from Peter H. Reynolds, Jerome discovers the magic of the words all around him. Short and sweet words, two-syllable treats, and multi-syllable words that sound like little songs are words featured in the work that connect, transform, and empower.

"It is a sweet story that encourages students to find their own meaningful words," said Carrie Vinson, librarian at North Hamilton.
text:
It's time for our first #HCSBookoftheWeek for the 2020-2021 school year!

The Word Collector by Peter H. Reynolds is this week's #HCSBookoftheWeek nominated by North Hamilton County Elementary. Some people collect stamps. Some people collect coins. Some people collect art. And Jerome? He collected words. In this extraordinary new tale from Peter H. Reynolds, Jerome discovers the magic of the words all around him. Short and sweet words, two-syllable treats, and multi-syllable words that sound like little songs are words featured in the work that connect, transform, and empower.

"It is a sweet story that encourages students to find their own meaningful words," said Carrie Vinson, librarian at North Hamilton.

post_text:
Hamilton County Schools is providing meals for students on online learning days:

-On-Campus Students in Extended Orientation: Students will have the opportunity to take home meals to cover the days they are learning virtually.

-HCS at Home Students: Parents may pick up meals on their student’s behalf each Wednesday between 9-10 a.m. through drive-up service at their child’s school. If parents have students enrolled in more than one school, they may pick up meals at any of the schools in which their children are enrolled.

Learn more: https://bit.ly/HCSStudentMeals

Hamilton County Schools is seeking leaders of faith-based and community-based organizations that are interested in launching Virtual Learning Centers to provide childcare and remote learning support for working families.

This is an opportunity for local organizations to fulfill a need in the community and to support the families they serve. There are multiple levels of engagement, everyone can participate in some way.

If you’re interested in launching a Virtual Learning Center, please fill out this form: https://bit.ly/30RAXWo

The district has also created a toolkit to provide guidance for interested partners: https://bit.ly/31pvBCo

post_text:
From Aug. 12 to Aug. 28, Hamilton County Schools is following an extended orientation A/B cohort schedule for Option 1 students called Safe Start, Great Start. Beginning Monday, Aug. 31, the district will use the latest active case data from the Hamilton County Health Department to determine what phase the district is in for on-campus learning.

The Phase Status Tracker below shows staff and families the phase the district will be in based on community health data from the Hamilton County Health Department. The decision for what phase will be used to determine the school schedule on Aug. 31 will be announced next Monday, Aug. 24.

*Note: The district will also use a rolling five-day average of student and teacher absences as a transition consideration. We will start using these numbers once there is enough data available to track the trends.

post_text:
Low-income eligible families can now enroll in HCS EdConnect, a program powered by EPB to connect over 17,000 students to free, high-speed WiFi.

Eligible families received an opt-in survey via email on Thursday, Aug. 6. Any family who received this email but did not respond will receive a text message survey today, Monday, Aug. 17. Please make sure your cell phone number is correct in PowerSchool to ensure you will receive the opt-in survey.

If you have questions about how to access PowerSchool or questions about your eligibility for the EdConnect program, please contact your child’s school.

post_text:
Now that students are back in school buildings, we encourage all families to review our return-to-school guidance. It is essential that children not attend school if they are sick, symptomatic, or waiting on COVID-19 test results. We recognize that keeping a child at home is a challenge for working families, but in order to keep our schools safe, it is imperative these students aren’t at school. Sending a child that may be sick to school puts other children and staff members at risk and could cause extended closures of schools. We ask you to please help us by keeping your child at home or not visiting the school if you are sick, symptomatic, or awaiting test results.

Please take a moment to review our return-to-school guidance for sick students.
text:
Now that students are back in school buildings, we encourage all families to review our return-to-school guidance. It is essential that children not attend school if they are sick, symptomatic, or waiting on COVID-19 test results. We recognize that keeping a child at home is a challenge for working families, but in order to keep our schools safe, it is imperative these students aren’t at school. Sending a child that may be sick to school puts other children and staff members at risk and could cause extended closures of schools. We ask you to please help us by keeping your child at home or not visiting the school if you are sick, symptomatic, or awaiting test results.

Please take a moment to review our return-to-school guidance for sick students.

post_text:
Beginning this year, all students will be able to use one username and password to access all of their virtual learning tools through our new single-sign on platform, ClassLink. To log in to ClassLink (http://launchpad.classlink.com/hcde), students will sign in with their Google account by selecting the "Sign in with Google" button.

The default password for student logins on Google is their date of birth in MMDDYYYY format. The username is the first initial + last initial + student number. Example: John Smith, 12345 would be js12345@students.hcde.org.

Students’ Google login information is also used to log in to student Chromebooks.

If the default password is not working for your student, please contact your student's teacher at the school for support.

*Note: Students in grades 6-12 have the ability to change their password after the initial login, so passwords may vary for students who have chosen a preferred password during previous school years.

post_text:
Beginning tomorrow, Aug. 12, meals will be provided for students on online learning days. These meals will be provided at the price the student would normally pay if they were in their school building. Parents can apply for free and reduced meal benefits online at http://www.hamilton.schoollunchapp.com. Students must be enrolled in HCS to receive meals.

HCS Learning Continuum Students in Phase 2: Students will have the opportunity to take home meals to cover the days they are learning virtually.

HCS at Home Students: Beginning Aug. 12, parents may pick up meals on their student’s behalf each Wednesday between 9-10 a.m. through drive-up service at their child’s school. If parents have students enrolled in more than one school, they may pick up meals at any of the schools in which their children are enrolled.

For more information, visit our website: https://www.hcde.org/cms/One.aspx?portalId=350278&pageId=30727450&fbclid=IwAR1IiO1mI8TSfeKgaY1GLAVPcErHAuySOwIYpIiBszceYZGaxJgD9CqFdxg

post_text:
We have announced the "Safe Start, Great Start" schedule for reopening through August 28. Beginning on August 31, we will follow the phased approach using our gating criteria data. Going forward, we will provide a daily update to show what phase we will be in on August 31 if the data was the same as today.

In addition, based on feedback and monitoring the data for the last several weeks, we will be using the rolling five-day average (weekdays not including weekends) for active cases instead of each day’s active case number. This will absorb any daily jumps and dips, ensuring less volatility in all of our key metrics. So, we will continue to publish the phase information on a daily basis, using the five-day rolling average of active cases, in anticipation of the August 31 implementation of the phase plan based on public health data.

On August 31, we will begin a two-week cadence in terms of operating in one phase before the data would move us to change. Of course, we would respond to any data that necessitated immediate closure, similar to our response to inclement weather.
text:
We have announced the "Safe Start, Great Start" schedule for reopening through August 28. Beginning on August 31, we will follow the phased approach using our gating criteria data. Going forward, we will provide a daily update to show what phase we will be in on August 31 if the data was the same as today.

In addition, based on feedback and monitoring the data for the last several weeks, we will be using the rolling five-day average (weekdays not including weekends) for active cases instead of each day’s active case number. This will absorb any daily jumps and dips, ensuring less volatility in all of our key metrics. So, we will continue to publish the phase information on a daily basis, using the five-day rolling average of active cases, in anticipation of the August 31 implementation of the phase plan based on public health data.

On August 31, we will begin a two-week cadence in terms of operating in one phase before the data would move us to change. Of course, we would respond to any data that necessitated immediate closure, similar to our response to inclement weather.

post_text:
HCS at Home students are expected to spend 6.5 hours per day engaged in learning, per the guidelines that the state department of education has set for an “instructional day.” Screen time will vary, but most students can expect a minimum of 2-3 hours of video lessons. Some supplemental lessons could include computer-based work, depending on the assignment.

*Note: Kindergarten students are only required to be engaged in learning for 4 hours per day, per state guidelines.

To view the full #HCSReopening FAQ, visit https://bit.ly/HCSReopeningFAQ.

We're excited to announce the launch of HCS EdConnect, a new initiative powered by EPB to provide internet services to 28,500 economically challenged students in Hamilton County Schools, at no charge. post_text:
All students and staff will be asked to commit to the HCS Pledge when attending school in person. The Pledge includes self-checking and tracking symptoms before coming to school each day. Symptoms include a fever, cough, tight chest, and other common symptoms of COVID-19. Anyone in an HCS building that begins to exhibit symptoms will be immediately isolated, then the school's Rapid Response team will manage the situation using the "Sick at School" protocols.

To view the full #HCSReopening FAQ, visit https://bit.ly/HCSReopeningFAQ.

post_text:
In Phase 2 and 3, all students are required to wear a face covering except as noted below. In K-2, we will ask all students to wear a face covering in the classroom. However, we will allow some flexibility for our youngest learners who need to remove masks inside the classroom, as long as they are with the same group of students they work with daily.

-A face covering is always required for all students and staff when outside of the classroom in the school building. The requirement includes K-2 students.
-The only exception is when students and staff are in a well-ventilated space that will accommodate social distancing. To be clear, a typical classroom would not meet these criteria. -A face covering will not be required when outdoors or in a large indoor space such as a gymnasium in which social distancing can be maintained, but it is still recommended.
-Each school will provide a safe space and time during the school day for students to remove the face covering if they wish.

To view the full #HCSReopening FAQ, visit https://bit.ly/HCSReopeningFAQ.

-The only exception is when students and staff are in a well-ventilated space that will accommodate social distancing. -August 12: A-Day, students assigned to A Days attend school.
-August 13: B-Day, students assigned to B Days attend school.
-August 14: Remote Learning Day, all students participate in remote learning from home.

To view the full #HCSReopening FAQ, visit https://bit.ly/HCSReopeningFAQ.

The school schedule for HCS at Home students will vary based on their zoned school. If their zoned school is 8:15 a.m. to 3:15 p.m., that is when teachers will expect them to be available for learning. Kindergarten students will only be learning for 4 hours per day, so their schedule will be tailored to what works best for them within the zoned school hours. #HCSatHome

The deadline to sign up your child for HCS at Home is July 22. Register at www.hcde.org/HCSatHome.

post_text:
We know there is a lot information for families to navigate with choices for the 2020-2021 school year, so we've created this decision tree to help families better understand the options available to them.

If your child is already registered for the school year, there is no action necessary for Option 1. The deadline to register for HCS at Home (Option 2) is July 22. Sign up at www.hcde.org/HCSatHome.

post_text:
HCS at Home students are expected to spend 6.5 hours per day on schoolwork. Screen time will vary, but most students can expect a minimum for 2-3 hours of video lessons. Some of their supplemental would could include computer-based work depending on the assignment. #HCSatHome

*Note: Kindergarten students will only be learning for 4 hours per day.

The deadline to sign your child up for HCS at Home is July 22. Register at www.hcde.org/HCSatHome.

Congratulations to these students for winning last week's #HCSSummerChallenge! These students completed at least five hours of reading and tracked it through our HCS Summer Learning Challenge tracker on our website.

Each week we'll randomly draw five students to win gift cards! To enter, a student must complete at least five hours of reading time and track it on our website. Students will receive one entry for every five hours of reading per week.

Submit your reading hours: www.hcde.org/SummerLearningChallenge

post_text:
Congratulations to Gary Wilkes, a band director in Hamilton County Schools, on his retirement! He has worked in the education field for 42 years, spending 27 years in Hamilton County Schools, and served students at CSAS and Red Bank High School.

Favorite Memory: “The incredible faculty and administration at CSAS, plus all of the great students I've taught.”

Thank you for your service to Hamilton County Schools!

To view our full list of 2020 retirees, visit https://www.hcde.org/HonoringOurRetirees.

Favorite Memory: “Children who gained confidence after taking part in a grade-level music program.”

post_text:
#HCSRetirees: Congratulations to Ron Hughes, principal at Apison Elementary, on his retirement! He has worked in the education field for 42 years, spending 36 years in Hamilton County Schools, and served students Apison Elementary, Alpine Crest Elementary, McConnell Elementary, Soddy Elementary, Allen Elementary, Brown Academy and Ooltewah Elementary.

Favorite Memory: “My favorite memory over my career was being selected as Tennessee Principal of the Year 2014-2015.”

Thank you for your service to Hamilton County Schools!

To view our full list of 2020 retirees, visit https://www.hcde.org/HonoringOurRetirees.

post_text:
#HCSRetirees: Congratulations to Demetris P. Jones, a teacher in Hamilton County Schools, on her retirement! She has worked in Hamilton County Schools for 26 years, and served students at Lakeside Academy, Hardy Elementary, and Garber Elementary.

Favorite Memory: “After being recognized and greeted by one of the students that I taught in first grade, the memorable moment came during his conversation with me. He told me he was in his twenties and had a good career. He told me he would never forget me because I made learning fun. He then went on to say how I had talked to and comforted him at a difficult time in his life. This short conversation with this past student will remain a cherished memory.”

Thank you for your service to Hamilton County Schools!

To view our full list of 2020 retirees, visit https://www.hcde.org/HonoringOurRetirees.

post_text:
#HCSRetirees: Congratulations to Kathy Campbell, a teacher in Hamilton County Schools, on her retirement! She has worked in the education field for 40 years, spending 30 years in Hamilton County Schools, and served students at Birchwood Elementary and Lookout Valley Elementary.

Favorite Memory: “My favorite memory is every day of my teaching career! When an adult comes up to you with a big smile on their face and says, ‘I was in your pre-k class and I loved the stories you told us, you made school fun!’”

Thank you for your service to Hamilton County Schools!

To view our full list of 2020 retirees, visit https://www.hcde.org/HonoringOurRetirees.

#HCSRetirees: Congratulations to Doris Thompson, an education assistant in Hamilton County Schools, on her retirement! She has worked in Hamilton County Schools for 20 years, and served students at Calvin Donaldson Environmental Science Academy.

Favorite Memory: “Reading coach with first. and second graders who thought they could not read but I was able to help them to realize, with a little encouragement, that they can read more than they thought.”

Thank you for your service to Hamilton County Schools!

To view our full list of 2020 retirees, visit https://www.hcde.org/HonoringOurRetirees.

post_text: A special message from Dr. Bryan Johnson to our seniors as they officially graduate from Hamilton County Schools this weekend. Congratulations, Class of 2020! #HCSco2020
text: A special message from Dr. Bryan Johnson to our seniors as they officially graduate from Hamilton County Schools this weekend. Congratulations, Class of 2020! #HCSco2020

post_text:
One of today’s #HCSco2020 Senior Spotlights is Lauren Abigail Martin, a senior at Soddy Daisy High School. Lauren is graduating in the Top 10% of her class and was recently chosen as “Best All Around” by her classmates. She is also student body co-president and has participated in soccer, tennis, FCA, National Honor Society, and the Beta Club.

After graduation, Lauren will attend the University of Tennessee at Chattanooga with plans to one day become a flight attendant.

post_text:
#HCSRetirees: Congratulations to Deborah Campbell, a math teacher in Hamilton County Schools, on her retirement! She has worked in Hamilton County Schools for 16 years, and served students at Tyner Academy.

Favorite Memory: “I have many favorite memories from great lunch room conversations with co-workers, to going to every football and basketball game for the last 12 years as cheerleader sponsor, to the relationship formed with other teachers as a clinical instructor, and most of all to the relationship formed with the wonderful students at Tyner Academy.”

Thank you for your service to Hamilton County Schools!

To view our full list of 2020 retirees, visit https://www.hcde.org/HonoringOurRetirees.

post_text: School Reopening Panel Discussion
text: School Reopening Panel Discussion

post_text:
Tonight the School Reopening Task Force will host a virtual panel to discuss their process for developing our plan for the reopening of schools on August 12. The session will include a Q&A for the community to ask questions about the development of the plan.

Please Note: This is a discussion about the process for developing the plan, not the specific details of the plan. A draft of the school reopening plan will be released to the public tomorrow, June 26, and there will be many more engagement opportunities to ask questions about the specifics of the plan.

The School Reopening Panel Discussion is tonight at 5:30 p.m. on Zoom. The session will also be streamed on our social media channels for public viewing. We are anticipating the call will exceed capacity, so if you do not plan to submit a question for the Q&A please consider watching the livestream on Facebook or YouTube.

One of today’s #HCSco2020 Senior Spotlights is Makayla Capers, a senior at Ooltewah High School.

“She’s a smart, kind hearted, loving girl, and is the first in our family to graduate high school,” said Jason Capers, one of Makayla’s family members. “We’re so very proud of her.”

After graduation, Makayla will attend Chattanooga State Community College with plans to transfer to a university after receiving an associates degree.

#HCSRetirees: Congratulations to Mary Reagan, a cosmetology instructor in Hamilton County Schools, on her retirement! She has worked in Hamilton County Schools for 35 years, and served students at Sequoyah High School.

Favorite Memory: “Too many favorite memories to mention just one...funniest is when cosmetology students lost control of the shampoo water hose and soaked anyone/everyone close by the area which became known as the ‘Splash Zone.’”

Thank you for your service to Hamilton County Schools!

To view our full list of 2020 retirees, visit https://www.hcde.org/HonoringOurRetirees.

One of today’s #HCSco2020 Senior Spotlights is Jonathan Jones, a senior at Soddy Daisy High School. Jonathan is a determined student who overcame personal obstacles to excel in the Soddy Daisy Marching Band, Concert Band, Wind Ensemble, and Jazz Band (soloist). He’s also been a part of the First Place-winning Special Olympics Bowling Team for three years.

Jonathan is currently employed at BlueCross BlueShield of Tennessee as part of the Project Search Program and will continue to work there after graduation.

post_text:
One of today’s #HCSco2020 Senior Spotlights is Alexis D’Chelle Pope, a senior at Chattanooga High Center for Creative Arts. Alexis worked hard to improve her GPA after transferring to a new school and missing classes because of knee surgery. She finished her senior year with a 3.2 GPA and made Honor Roll first quarter and Star Roll the last three quarters. She also interned with CBL for two summers.

After graduation, Alexis will attend the University of Tennessee at Chattanooga to study accounting and finance.

post_text:
One of today’s #HCSco2020 Senior Spotlights is Jason Tran, a senior at East Hamilton High School. Jason is an excellent student and is valedictorian of his class. He’s a member of both the marching and concert band, Model UN, Mu Alpha Theta, Youth in Government, Tennessee Governor’s School for the Arts (2018), National English Honor Society, National Honor Society, and the Youth Leadership Forum on Medicine (2019).

After graduation, Jason plans to attend Rice University to study biology with an emphasis on pre-medicine.

post_text:
#HCSRetirees: Congratulations to Dr. Marthel Young, principal at East Brainerd Elementary, on her retirement! She has worked in Hamilton County Schools for 35 years, and served students at East Brainerd Elementary, Rivermont Elementary, Orchard Knob Elementary, and DuPont Elementary.

Favorite Memory: “I have many wonderful memories. I believe one of my most favorite memories has been when children of any age get so excited about exploring and discovery, and watching how they are empowered to take ownership of their learning. Another wonderful memory that I will cherish is having had the privilege to serve with so many wonderful extraordinary educators over the years who have enabled me to laugh, grow, learn and relearn, and to start all over again.”

Thank you for your service to Hamilton County Schools!

To view our full list of 2020 retirees, visit https://www.hcde.org/HonoringOurRetirees.

One of today’s #HCSco2020 Senior Spotlights is Caleb Fisher, a senior at Ooltewah High School. Caleb is Salutatorian of his class and an International Baccalaureate Diploma student. He is also the leader of the HOO Club Outdoor Classroom and Owl Sanctuary Committee. During his time at OHS, he researched an application of the sieve in functional programming through the IB program and led an initiative for water bottle filling stations and received a $1,000 grant from Arch Plastics. Caleb is currently an intern with Hamilton County Schools’ Human Resources team and is an active member of his church, including a mission trip to Mexico where he helped construct an addition to the church and led Bible study programs for children.

After graduation, Caleb plans to attend the University of Tennessee at Knoxville to double major in electrical engineering and mathematics.

One of today’s #HCSco2020 Senior Spotlights is Megan Long, a senior at CSAS. Megan has attended CSAS since kindergarten and excelled during her time there. He was also picked for Best of Preps in both football and wrestling for this year. While playing three sports, Hayden has maintained a 3.1 GPA and earned a 25 on his ACT.

After graduation, Hayden will attend Cleveland State Community College on a baseball scholarship.

post_text:
#HCSRetirees: Congratulations to Dr. Mary Baker Hendricks, a P.E. teacher in Hamilton County Schools, on her retirement! She has worked in Hamilton County Schools for 21 years, and served students at Howard Elementary, Eastside Elementary, White Oak Elementary, Hillcrest Elementary, Hardy Elementary, Clifton Hills Elementary, and Orchard Knob Elementary.

Favorite Memory: “I had a student struggling with her weight. I encouraged her to exercise (60 minutes) every day by walking. I saw her some years later. She was in high school. She looked fantastic. As a result of that encouragement to her, she told me that she and her mother lost weight together by walking. She also shared they were eating and living healthy. My aim as a Health and Physical Education teacher was to impress on my students the importance of a healthy body. ‘If your body feels good, then your cognitive, mental, social and spiritual health will be impacted as well.’”

Thank you for your service to Hamilton County Schools!

To view our full list of 2020 retirees, visit https://www.hcde.org/HonoringOurRetirees.

One of today’s #HCSco2020 Senior Spotlights is Annabelle Sapp, a senior at Soddy Daisy High School. Annabelle is a hardworking student who is involved in her community. She received the TASC Star Award and Impact Award for outstanding community service. She also served as junior class president and is currently the president of the National Honor Society. She is the student council chaplain and a member of the Beta Club and Interact Club. Annabelle is also the 2020 Distinguished Young Woman of Soddy Daisy. She has balanced all of this school and community involvement while maintaining a 3.985 GPA.

After graduation, Annabelle will study exercise science with plans to enter a physical therapy program.

“She has many talents to offer the world from singing to bass guitar,” her mom said. “Olivia can pick up anything and it turns to gold. She has always been the social butterfly since she was little. Olivia has a heart to advocate for children who have no voice and help improve their quality of life. Her inner beauty is just stunning as her outward and I know she will do great things.”

After graduation, Olivia will attend Chattanooga State to study social and behavioral science.

post_text:
One of today’s #HCSco2020 Senior Spotlights is Aiden Gaston, a senior at CSAS. Aiden is a hard-working student who cares about his friends and his community. He is a member of the CSAS Orchestra, the Paideia Society, the Chattanooga Junior Rowing team, and is active in his church. For this senior project, he did an internship in Adaptive Technology at Signal Centers. When the project and internship were derailed by the school closure, he shifted his focus to 3D printing “ear savers” for healthcare workers wearing PPE all day.

After graduation, Aiden plans to attend the University of Tennessee at Knoxville where he will study biomedical engineering. He has also been invited to be in the Chancellor’s Honors Program.

post_text:
One of today’s #HCSco2020 Senior Spotlights is Connor Thornburg, a senior at East Hamilton High School. Connor is a student-athlete who has played on the varsity football, baseball, and wrestling teams. He received multiple offers to play football and baseball at the collegiate level. He is also a member of Young Life, FCA, the National honor Society, and the leadership class.

“He is always willing to step up and help East Hamilton and the community,” said Lindsay Donahue, one of Connor’s teachers. “He went to local elementary schools to speak to students about academic success with other members of the football team, and whenever we needed help with anything, Conner was there. He is truly leaving a hole at East Hamilton.”

After graduation, Connor plans to attend Birmingham Southern on a football scholarship and will major in pre-health studies.

One of today’s #HCSco2020 Senior Spotlights is Olivia Stewart, a senior at East Hamilton High School. Olivia is senior class president, and served as class president all four years of high school. She also serves as CEO of her Virtual Enterprise class, captain of the cheer team, is a member of National Honor Society, and the Leadership Class.

“I’ve known Olivia for four years, and she has a heart of gold,” said Lindsay Donahue, one of Olivia’s teachers. “She works to improve East Hamilton in every way she possibly can. She has such school spirit and cares about her friends and her community so much. She has left such an impact on East Hamilton and will be truly missed.”

After graduation, Olivia will attend the University of Alabama to study marketing, finance and English.

One of today’s #HCSco2020 Senior Spotlights is Ashton Mayo-Beavers, a senior at Chattanooga High School Center for Creative Arts. Ashton is an excellent student who has maintained a 3.96 GPA and earned more than $96,000 in merit and scholarship awards. She’s been active in her community and is a member of the YMCA Leaders Club, Zeta Phi Beta Archonette Club, Girls Inc., IMPACT Group, National Honor Society, National Dance Honor Society, the Project Motion Dance Company with CCA, and interned with the United Way. Ashton has been asked to sit on several state and national panels for Girls Inc., PEF, and recognized for the Chalkboard publication discussing education and COVID-10. Her senior project was based on an app she created called Cultural DNA and Technology.

After graduation, Ashton will attend Mercer University to major in computer science.

In her free time, she coaches a youth soccer team called “The X-Factor” and works for her dad’s construction company.

“Emily will brighten anyone’s day just by walking in a room,” said Loreli Gonzalez, one of Emily’s classmates. “She always puts others first and will take up for anyone. She’s a role model to little girls all over the community!”

After graduation, Emily plans to attend Roane State on a softball scholarship and will pursue business.

#HCSRetirees: Congratulations to Vickie Spangler, a social worker for Hamilton County Schools, on her retirement! She has worked for Hamilton County Schools for 22 years, and served students at The Howard School, Calvin Donaldson Academy, Lookout Mountain Elementary, Clifton Hills Elementary, Franklin Middle School, Soddy Elementary, Soddy Daisy Middle, Soddy Daisy High, Allen Elementary, Sequoyah High, North Hamilton County Elementary, Sale Creek Middle High, and Daisy Elementary.

Favorite Memory: “My favorite memories are working with students and exceptional teachers and administrators. Knowing you are respected as a professional and part of the team is so meaningful. Specifically Mrs. Kim Roden and Mrs. Jaquie Hauth. Both have been a tremendous support during my tenure and I will never forget these two beautiful ladies.”

Thank you for your service to Hamilton County Schools!

To view our full list of 2020 retirees, visit https://www.hcde.org/HonoringOurRetirees.

One of today’s #HCSco2020 Senior Spotlights is Olivia Carter, a senior at East Hamilton High School. Olivia transferred from Illinois and was able to graduate early in December. She’s an active member of her community and has volunteered through her church and service organizations. Olivia is also a competitive dancer with the Infinity Dance Connection Senior Dance Team and has won several top place awards both in a group and as a solo dancer. She was first runner-up as Miss Fashionetta with the Ivy Rose Foundation of Alpha Kappa Alpha Sorority, Inc., and won first place in the essay contest.

After graduation, Olivia plans to attend Alabama State University to major in kinesiology and minor in dance.

The 2019-2020 school year ended in a very unusual way for Hamilton County Schools students and staff due to the COVID-19 pandemic. As we make plans for a safe reopening of school in the fall, we believe the summer provides us a unique opportunity to recover learning loss from the spring, maintain engagement, and also provide select students a head start for the 2020-2021 school year.

Learn more about summer learning opportunities here: https://t.e2ma.net/webview/4tz67c/151f89f17dc9954061e720d126577d56

One of today’s #HCSco2020 Senior Spotlights is Atania Jett, a senior at East Ridge High School. Atania is an excellent student that has maintained a 3.89 GPA and will graduate in the Top 10% of her class. She is a member of the National Honor Society and Beta Club, and has been involved in the TRIO Upward Bound Program at UTC for three years. She was also selected to do work-based learning at Gestamp, which allowed her to finish school early and work for the company full time.

After graduation, Atania will attend Johnson and Wales University in Miami.

She is also a student-athlete and has played on the school’s softball team as well as travel softball. Last year she earned the honor of District Player of the Year. She will graduate in the Top 10 % of her class and has balanced all of this while also working at Texas Roadhouse.

After graduation, Madison will attend Tennessee Wesleyan University on a softball scholarship and will major in special education.

One of today’s #HCSco2020 Senior Spotlights is Chloe Johnson, a senior at Ooltewah High School. Chloe is a talented student-athlete who played lacrosse all four years of high school. She made All Region in 2019 and serves as a team captain. She also plays summer lacrosse with Shine Lacrosse in Knoxville. Chloe is active in missions with her church, Bayside Baptist and Chattanooga/Ooltewah FCA.

After graduation, Chloe will attend the University of Alabama at Huntsville to play lacrosse. She also plans to join ROTC and will study psychology and military science.

#HCSRetirees: Congratulations to Ann-Marie Blentlinger, a 7th grade ELA and social studies teacher in Hamilton County Schools, on her retirement! She has worked in Hamilton County Schools for 30 years, and served students at CSLA, Red Bank Middle, Soddy Elementary, Spring Creek Elementary, Wallace A. Smith Elementary, and Harrison Elementary.

Favorite Memory: “It is impossible to choose just one favorite memory after 30 years of teaching because I have had the privilege of knowing so many wonderful students and colleagues. However, the Fund for Teachers trip I took to Kenya with my colleague, Karen West, stands out as an adventure of a lifetime since we were able to share our teaching skills with teachers and students at Kamangu Primary School outside of Nairobi, Kenya.”

Thank you for your service to Hamilton County Schools!

To view our full list of 2020 retirees, visit https://www.hcde.org/HonoringOurRetirees.

One of today’s #HCSco2020 Senior Spotlights is Hunter Loomis, a senior at Sale Creek High School. Hunter is a hard-working student-athlete who has maintained a 3.9 GPA throughout high school. He is a member of the National Honor Society and will graduate in the Top 10% of his class. He played basketball and soccer all four years of high school, and has been recognized in both sports. Hunter participated in “Sale Creek Abroad,” a student exchange program that hosted students from France. Last summer, he visited some of the students and spent time with them at their school in France.

After graduation, Hunter will attend the University of Tennessee at Chattanooga to pursue an engineering degree.

post_text:
One of today’s #HCSco2020 Senior Spotlights is Gavon Wishon, a senior at Hixson High School.

“Gavon is an amazing young man who has a heart of gold,” said Angela Nowitzke, Gavon’s mother. “He constantly helps out with his younger siblings, elderly in need, and neighbors. He lights up a room with his energetic personality. He has overcome many hurdles in the past four years to get to where he is at. No matter what life has thrown at him he has persevered. I couldn’t be more proud of the young man he has become and I look forward to seeing what the future holds for him.”

After graduation, Gavon plans to attend college to study business.

One of today’s #HCSco2020 Senior Spotlights is Payton Albritton, a senior at Signal Mountain Middle/High School. Payton is a high achieving student who has maintained a 4.0 GPA and taking AP and dual enrollment classes. She is a member of the National Honor Society and Beta Club, and volunteers with the Leo Club. She is a leader on the softball team, receiving All County and the Silver Slugger Award two years in a row for having the highest batting average on the team. She is also actively involved with her youth group at Mount Carmel Baptist Church. She has done all of this while working a part-time job.

After graduation, Payton will attend the University of Tennessee at Knoxville.

One of today’s #HCSco2020 Senior Spotlights is Allison O’Rafferty, a senior at Sequoyah High School.

“Allison is graduating sixth in her class despite many obstacles in her life,” said Cristina Phillips, one of Allison’s teachers. “She is one of the hardest working, kindest students I have ever had in my teaching career. She is fluent in sign language (two of her sisters are deaf). Allison is also in the leadership program at SHS and has been on the prom committee for two years.”

After graduation, Allison plans to attend Chattanooga State Community College to pursue a degree in sign language so she can become an interpreter.

He also received the National High School Model United Nations Award of Merit for Small and Medium Sized Delegations, the Tennessee YMCA Youth in Government Outstanding States Person Award and Outstanding Billing Award.

After graduation, Benjamin will attend the University of Arkansas to study math and computer science.

SACC Update: There will not be a need for a lottery to fill slots for School Age Child Care sites in Hamilton County Schools this summer. Approximately 400 children were registered at the planned 25 locations for this summer.

Five sites went over the 25 student limit in registrations, but we have already worked with parents at those locations to move children to other sites to get all children registered into a program for the summer.

Cade has demonstrated outstanding leadership skills during his time at Ooltewah High by serving as raider commander and command sergeant major of the JROTC Battalion. After graduation, Cade will be attending the University of Tennessee at Knoxville on a four-year Air Force ROTC Scholarship. He will be studying civil engineering.

After graduation, Eliza will attend a four-year college.

Today will be the last day for student meal delivery. There will be no meal pickup on Friday, May 22, or Monday, May 25.

Beginning Tuesday, May 26, our summer meal pickup sites will begin service. These sites will be open on Tuesdays and Fridays from 11 a.m. to 1 p.m. On Tuesdays, families will be able to pick up three days of meals, and on Fridays, they will receive four days of meals.

Below are the summer meal sites:

• Bess T Shepherd
• Harrison Elementary
• Spring Creek
• East Ridge Elementary
• East Lake Elementary
• Clifton Hills
• Orchard Knob Elementary
• Hardy Elementary
• Soddy Elementary
• Middle Valley Elementary
• Hixson High

• Nolan Elementary

One of today’s #HCSco2020 Senior Spotlights is Kaislyn Gunnels, a senior at Hixson High School.

“Kaislyn is always such a light at Hixson and has not met a person that she does not greet with kindness and humility,” said Erin White, one of Kaislyn’s teachers. “When I was a brand new teacher, Kaislyn was in my advisory class. Instead of taking advantage of my lack of knowledge of school traditions, she explained each tradition to me in great detail. My first year teaching would have been much harder had she not been in my class.”

After graduation, Kaislyn will attend the University of Tennessee at Chattanooga to study education and Spanish.

#HCSTop10: #6 - Hamilton County Schools Has the Most Schools Earn the STEM Designation From the State for 2020

Five Hamilton County Schools were among 22 state-wide awarded the Tennessee STEM School Designation for 2020 in a recent announcement by the Tennessee Department of Education. Red Bank Elementary, Harrison Elementary, Red Bank High, Hixson Middle, and Normal Park Museum Magnet are the five schools in Hamilton County Schools earning the state designation for their work in science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM.) The Tennessee Department of Education and the STEM Leadership Council worked together to develop the designation as a way to identify and recognize schools for their commitment to teaching STEM or STEAM (science, technology, engineering, arts, and mathematics) and for their work to prepare students for college and career success. The five schools join STEM School Chattanooga as district schools with the Tennessee STEM School Designation

The Tennessee Department of Education and the STEM Leadership Council worked together to develop the designation as a way to identify and recognize schools for their commitment to teaching STEM or STEAM (science, technology, engineering, arts, and mathematics) and for their work to prepare students for college and career success. The five schools join STEM School Chattanooga as district schools with the Tennessee STEM School Designation

One of today’s #HCSco2020 Senior Spotlights is Alex Gifford, a senior at Hixson High School.

“He has been an awesome help in our e-Lab and is constantly coming up to solutions to problems we didn't even know that we had,” said Erin White, one of Alex’s teachers. “His mind works in ways that I can't even begin to wrap my head around, and he is a great problem solver. He is not one to brag about his accomplishments, but everything he has he has worked hard to earn on his own, and he should be very proud of how far he has come!”

After graduation, Alex plans to attend the University of Tennessee at Knoxville.

post_text:
One of today’s #HCSco2020 Senior Spotlights is Natalee Clem, a senior at CSAS. After the school experienced a tragedy, Natalee felt her classmates needed a safe place to go when they were struggling with their emotions. With permission from the principal and librarian, she secured a space she could transform into a “calm room” for students to de-stress or spend a few minutes in quiet reflection. She conducted hours of research and met with community leaders to learn about mindfulness and various kinds of therapy including art and music therapy. Natalee collected donations from parents for the space and worked in the eLab to build shelves for the room. She did all of this while also serving as a member of the Student Government Association, Honor Society, and working a part-time job. Natalee planned to have an open house to showcase the room in March, but had to cancel due to COVID-19.

After graduation, Natalee plans to pursue a degree in interior architecture.

Jeremiah has faced health issues since he was a child and persevered to successfully complete his senior year of high school. He’s been a part of the Big Brother Big Sisters program since 2nd grade, which has encouraged him and helped shape him into the young man he is today. Jeremiah is also involved in his community, and volunteers at McKamey Animal Shelter, the Chattanooga Community Kitchen, and the Chattanooga Food Bank.

After graduation, Jeremiah plans to attend Freed Hardeman University to pursue a major in computer science.

post_text:
#HCSTop10: #7 - Office of Innovation and Choice Begins With HCS Recognized as a Global Leader in Fab Labs

Hamilton County Schools, in partnership with Volkswagen Group of America Chattanooga Operations, LLC, the State of Tennessee, and the Public Education Foundation, celebrated the Fab Foundation recognizing Hamilton County Schools as an international leader in digital fabrication education at a news conference held in September at Dalewood Middle School. The Fab Foundation is a Boston-based non-profit organization that emerged from MIT's Center for Bits & Atoms Fab Lab Program, where students learn how to make virtually anything. The Fab Foundation's leadership team has worked with Hamilton County Schools since 2017 through the Public Education Foundation.

Hamilton County Schools now represents the world's largest concentration of educational Fab Labs in any community, with 17 labs joining the Foundation's Fab Lab Network. The labs include one at STEM School Chattanooga and the 16 Volkswagen eLabs in Hamilton County Schools opened since 2017.

Today #IAmHamilton spotlights Cindy Pointer, a physical education teacher at Red Bank Elementary. Pointer has been at Red Bank for 33 years and is treasured by the children, their parents, the school staff, and the community.

"Cindy Pointer is a rock at RBE, and every student (and most parents) know who she is and have a good relationship with her," wrote Christie Crowe, a counselor at Red Bank Elementary, in her nomination. "Cindy strives hard to know every student in the school, and she is pretty much every student's "go-to" person at the school."

Today #IAmHamilton spotlights Cindy Pointer, a physical education teacher at Red Bank Elementary. Pointer has been at Red Bank for 33 years and is treasured by the children, their parents, the school staff, and the community.

"Cindy Pointer is a rock at RBE, and every student (and most parents) know who she is and have a good relationship with her," wrote Christie Crowe, a counselor at Red Bank Elementary, in her nomination. "Cindy strives hard to know every student in the school, and she is pretty much every student's "go-to" person at the school."

post_text: One of today’s #HCSco2020 Senior Spotlights is Melissa Fienga, a senior at Hixson High School. Melissa is a dedicated member of the Hixson softball team and was team captain this year. She was disappointed to miss her senior softball season, but has been putting her time at home to good use by applying to several colleges. After graduation, Melissa has not decided on a college but plans to attend a nursing program in Tennessee so she can give back to her community.

Amarah is captain of the basketball team and will graduate in the Top 10% of her class with a 3.9 GPA. Ahmad serves as class president and has maintained a 3.2 GPA. He was also crowned Mr. BHS.

After graduation, Amarah and Ahmad will both attend Middle Tennessee State University.

post_text:
We're counting down the Top 10 Highlights of the 2019-2020 School Year as we wind down the school year. #HCSTop10

#9 - 20 Schools Received Musical Instruments and Training from Usher and Little Kids Rock

In March, Usher’s Nancy Lackey Community Education Fund and national music education nonprofit, Little Kids Rock, announced a partnership to launch Little Kids Rock’s highly inclusive, culturally relevant, and innovative music education programs in 20 Hamilton County Schools. More than 3,500 students will benefit from the unique curriculum and instruments donated to the schools.

One of today’s #HCSco2020 Senior Spotlights is Madison Reeves, a senior at Ooltewah High School. Madison has maintained excellent grades and a positive attitude through some challenging moments during her high school career. She is a member of the Beta and Honor Society, OHS Leadership, and OHS Yearbook Staff. She is also captain of the varsity cheerleading squad, earned All-American for the last two years, and was also selected as an Tennessee All State Cheerleader for 2019-2020.

After graduation, Madison will attend the University of Tennessee at Chattanooga to pursue a degree in nursing. Her ultimate goal is to become a nurse practitioner that specializes in neonatal patients.

After graduation, Isaac will attend the University of Alabama at Huntsville where he will study aerospace engineering.

post_text:
Congratulations are in order! Five Hamilton County Schools are among 22 state-wide awarded the Tennessee STEM School Designation for 2020.

The Tennessee Department of Education and the STEM Leadership Council worked together to develop the designation as a way to identify and recognize schools for their commitment to teaching STEM or STEAM (science, technology, engineering, arts, and mathematics) and for their work to prepare students for college and career success.

The selection of five schools in Hamilton County is the most from one district in the state for 2020. The five schools join STEM School Chattanooga as district schools with the Tennessee STEM School Designation.
text:
Congratulations are in order! Five Hamilton County Schools are among 22 state-wide awarded the Tennessee STEM School Designation for 2020.

The Tennessee Department of Education and the STEM Leadership Council worked together to develop the designation as a way to identify and recognize schools for their commitment to teaching STEM or STEAM (science, technology, engineering, arts, and mathematics) and for their work to prepare students for college and career success.

The selection of five schools in Hamilton County is the most from one district in the state for 2020. The five schools join STEM School Chattanooga as district schools with the Tennessee STEM School Designation.

The PBS At Home Learning Series: Teaching Tennessee is providing 1st-6th grade students standards-aligned instructional lessons on ELA and Math available on their local PBS station. All lessons, including 7th and 8th grade lessons, will be available on the department’s YouTube page.

Students, families, and educators can find teacher guides, student packets, and additional resources for using the PBS videos on the department's website: https://www.us8.list-manage.com/track/click?u=b28b453ee164f9a2e2b5057e1&id=551b2f1d06&e=47327db5f4

One of today’s #HCSco2020 Senior Spotlights is Jordan Hudson, a senior at Central High School. Jordan has maintained a 3.8 GPA throughout high school. He is also Central High School’s 2020 Homecoming King, Voted Best All Around, Honor Society President, Color Guard Commander in ROTC, and has been an active volunteer in the community for several years. He also works a part-time job at Zaxby’s to save money for college.

“He is highly motivated and very talented,” said Shedesha Hudson, Jordan’s mother. “He has compassion and respect for others and it's noticed wherever he goes. I am extremely proud of my son.”

After graduation, Jordan plans to attend Middle Tennessee State University to pursue a degree in nursing.

Today is School Lunch Heroes Day, and we’re celebrating our amazing cafeteria staff! These employees play an integral role in students’ school day, and we’re proud to have them on our team. Even when students weren’t at school due to the COVID-19 closure, our cafeteria staff stepped up to prepare meals for families so our students have food at home.

We love our School Lunch Heroes!

post_text:
One of today’s #HCSco2020 Senior Spotlights is Jordan Morris, a senior at CSAS. Jordan is an exceptional student who has maintained a 4.0 GPA while primarily taking honors classes. He has also excelled as an athlete, serving as captain of both the basketball and baseball teams, making all district in basketball for two years, and being named co-MVP of the regular season in basketball this year. He was also selected for the all regional team this year in baseball.

Jordan is also very involved in his school and the community. He is a member of the Mayor’s Youth Council, Chattanooga Ambassadors Program, the Audio/Visual Club, Paedia Honor Society, Urban League National Achievers, served on the Mock Youth Court, and is the president of the Kappa Leadership League. He has also received awards for chemistry, Spanish, and positive behavior. Jordan has been able to accomplish all of these things while also balancing being a Type 1 Diabetic.

After graduation, Jordan will attend the University of Tennessee at Knoxville to pursue aeronautical engineering.
text:
One of today’s #HCSco2020 Senior Spotlights is Jordan Morris, a senior at CSAS. Jordan is an exceptional student who has maintained a 4.0 GPA while primarily taking honors classes. He has also excelled as an athlete, serving as captain of both the basketball and baseball teams, making all district in basketball for two years, and being named co-MVP of the regular season in basketball this year. He was also selected for the all regional team this year in baseball.

Jordan is also very involved in his school and the community. He is a member of the Mayor’s Youth Council, Chattanooga Ambassadors Program, the Audio/Visual Club, Paedia Honor Society, Urban League National Achievers, served on the Mock Youth Court, and is the president of the Kappa Leadership League. He has also received awards for chemistry, Spanish, and positive behavior. Jordan has been able to accomplish all of these things while also balancing being a Type 1 Diabetic.

After graduation, Jordan will attend the University of Tennessee at Knoxville to pursue aeronautical engineering.

post_text:
Today’s #HCSco2020 Senior Spotlight is Mollie Bishop, a senior at Hixson High School. Mollie is a talented writer and communicator who invests her skills in causes she cares about. Most recently, she spent some of her virtual learning time researching the role of Tennessee in the women's suffrage movement and prepared a speech for the Tennessee State Library and Archives and the Tennessee State Museum's "Battle for the Ballot" speech competition.

“I admire Mollie's willingness to engage in academic challenges above and beyond her full class load and the demands of multiple extra-curricular activities,” said Stephanie Brewer, Mollie’s former teacher. “As a history teacher, I applaud Mollie's focus on civics-related activities, and I look forward to following how she takes her passion for equity into the next stages of her life.”

After graduation, Mollie plans to pursue a degree in elementary education at the University of Tennessee at Chattanooga.

post_text:
The second round of the Choose Hamilton application is currently open. This application includes select Magnet, Open Enrollment, and Early Post-Secondary options and adds Lookout Mountain School as a new Open Enrollment option for the 2020-21 school year.

The deadline to apply to Lookout Mountain School is April 29. The lottery for Lookout Mountain will be on May 4.

The other Magnet, Open Enrollment, and Early Post-Secondary options will accept applications on a first-come, first-serve basis.

Choose Hamilton gives all families in Hamilton County Schools the option for your children to attend a school outside of your neighborhood zoned school.

To submit your application and learn more about school choice, please visit the district’s website at www.hcde.org/ChooseHamilton.

If you have already submitted a choice application for the 2020-21 school year, please email choosehamilton@hcde.org to update your choice options.

Hamilton County Schools has set up a tornado relief supply center at CSLA (6579 East Brainerd Road) to support our families who were impacted by the tornado.

IF YOU ARE IN NEED:
Families can pick up tornado relief items today from 12-2 p.m. Families will be asked to share the name and school of their student so that address may be verified. Your child does not have to attend CSLA to receive resources.

IF YOU ARE DONATING:
We are collecting donations at CSLA on Saturday from 10 a.m.-2 p.m.

ITEMS NEEDED:

Cleaning Supplies:
- Wipes
- Mopping Solution
- Paper Towels

Food/Snacks:
- Chips
- Protein Bars
- Crackers
- Packaged Foods

Body Care:
- Dry Shampoo
- Deodorant
- Laundry Supplies

Gift Cards:
-Walmart
-Fast Food
-Local Restaurants
-Lowe’s
-Home Depot

#BetterTogether

Today #IAmHamilton spotlights Gena Thompson, a parent volunteer at Brown Academy. She is a former combat medic and shared about veterans for Veterans Day wearing her uniform. Thompson was a major factor in the school's participation in the Jump Rope for Heart pledge drive.

The Thompson family (mom, dad, grandmother, and kids) is very involved at Brown Academy. They participate in all of the fundraisers and events. Gena Thompson provides healthy snacks and supplies for multiple classrooms. She also is a positive role model and cheerleader for the school and children.

In an effort to help the community, we will add a donation site at Hixson Middle School to help Hamilton County families who have been impacted by the tornado damage this week.

We are accepting the following items:
-Bottled Gatorade or Powerade
-Bottled water
-Bleach
-Rakes
-Shovels
-Diapers
-Garbage Bags
-Female sanitary items
-Baby wipes
-Any restaurant, home improvement store, or grocery gift cards.

Donations may be dropped off at Hixson Middle School at the following times:
-Wednesday, April 15 - 5-7 p.m.
-Thursday, April 16 - 8-11 a.m. and 5-7 p.m.
-Friday, April 17 - 8-11 a.m.

These items will be taken to the CSLA pickup site for distribution. We thank you for your helping hand in caring for our Hamilton County families and neighbors. #BetterTogether

post_text:
Hamilton County Schools will be reopening the school choice application for several schools. See the information below for how the process will work for each school.

-Choice Schools: These are schools that were included in our original choice lottery and have capacity to add more students. They will be taking applications on a first-come, first-serve basis.
-New Choice School: Lookout Mountain Elementary is a new addition to our choice schools. There will be a lottery at the end of the application window.
-Early Postsecondary Options: These schools are accepting applications through June 15.
text:
Hamilton County Schools will be reopening the school choice application for several schools. See the information below for how the process will work for each school.

-Choice Schools: These are schools that were included in our original choice lottery and have capacity to add more students. They will be taking applications on a first-come, first-serve basis.
-New Choice School: Lookout Mountain Elementary is a new addition to our choice schools. There will be a lottery at the end of the application window.
-Early Postsecondary Options: These schools are accepting applications through June 15.

It will also allow students to take a break and explore art, music, science explorations, dance, or the related art form of their choice. Some students may even elect to spend the day enjoying their favorite books. We hope students enjoy a day to refresh their minds with hands-on STEAM activities.

Share your activities with us using #HCSFullSTEAM on social media.

post_text:
Today bus drivers will deliver meals to students in need by making stops on all of the elementary morning routes. To find your stop, select the elementary school closest to you on our Bus Stop Finder (https://bit.ly/3advWdm) or call the transportation hotline at (423) 498-5555.

Once you've found your bus stop, find the corresponding bus number here: https://bit.ly/2xkiFRE

Here are the time frames for the student meal delivery:

-Special Education Routes - 11 a.m. - 12 p.m.
-Buses 1-111- 11:15 a.m. - 12 p.m.
-Buses 300-499 - 12 p.m. - 1 p.m.

All meals are provided free to children up to age 18. Families do not need to provide proof of school enrollment, income, or free/reduced lunch eligibility. Children must be present to receive the meals.

There will still be some school sites available if families prefer to pick up the meals. The list of school sites is on our website: http://bit.ly/3d68osz

post_text:
Hamilton County Schools is working with a variety of community partners to identify options for providing internet access to as many families as possible to ensure students can continue their learning.

-Comcast has opened its WiFi hotspots for public access.
-EPB is installing 25 EPB Quick Connect free WiFi locations across the community. View the current locations at https://www.techgoeshomecha.org/epb.html. This is an ongoing process, so check this website regularly for updates.

Hamilton County Schools is also working to identify the best option for rapidly providing in-home internet access to as many students as possible.

Here are some additional WiFi resources.

Free Public WiFi Map: http://bit.ly/2WrifTQ

Low Cost WiFi Connectivity Options: http://bit.ly/2WoUuvO

#HCSContinuedLearning

post_text:
In an effort to keep families and students engaged during our school closure, we are excited to announce that we are partnering with our local PBS station, WTCI-TV, to bring educational programming to households in Hamilton County.

Tonight we will be kicking off this partnership with an HCS Continued Learning live broadcast at 8 p.m. District leaders will be sharing information and resources to support families while schools are closed, including access to food, supports, and Wifi as well as tips for parents who are educating their children at home. The program will also include an opportunity for viewers at home to call in and ask questions.

The program will also include an opportunity for viewers at home to call in and ask questions.

post_text:
According to new guidance, if a student is showing COVID-19 symptoms please alert your healthcare provider and the Hamilton County Health Department. The appropriate time to contact the school is after a student has tested positive for COVID-19.

This will help cut down on the number of inquires our school staff are currently receiving. Thank you!

post_text:
In an abundance of caution, the below school buildings will be closed tomorrow, March 16, for a priority cleaning. These schools reported someone in their building with some level of contact with a confirmed COVID-19 case or someone experiencing symptoms similar to COVID-19. The school buildings will be reopened on Tuesday, March 17.

-East Ridge Middle School
-Ooltewah Elementary School
-The Howard School
-Battle Academy

As a reminder, schools are closed this week. Some buildings will be open during the week for pickup for meals, learning packets, and learning devices.

For more information on how COVID-19 is affecting Hamilton County Schools, visit www.hcde.org/coronavirus.

post_text: This week Usher’s Nancy Lackey Community Education Fund and national music education nonprofit, Little Kids Rock, announced a partnership to launch Little Kids Rock’s highly inclusive, culturally relevant, and innovative music education programs in 20 new Hamilton County Schools. More than 3,500 students will benefit from the unique curriculum and instrument donation, including guitars, drums, keyboards, drum sets, and more. #HCSLeadsArts

post_text: Hamilton County Schools continues to shine as a beacon of innovative education across the country. This week, more than 40 leaders from 10 school districts in central Indiana visited to get a first-hand experience in the digital fabrication and STEM ecosystems in Hamilton County Schools. The visit showcased a variety of innovative practices in the VW eLabs at Dalewood Middle School, Soddy Daisy Middle School, Hixson Middle School, and STEM School Chattanooga. #HCSLeads

post_text:
Today #IAmHamilton spotlights Airicka Richardson & Jack Graham, sophomores at Central HS. The two worked to bring back an alumnus, who was one of the first African American students to integrate Central, to talk with history classes as part of a Black History Month presentation.

"The project for Black History Month was spearheaded by two of my students who were inspired by Mr. Justice,” said Laura Costello, gifted teacher at Central High. “Airicka and Jack realized the significance of Mr. Justice’s role in the history of Central High.”

post_text:
Today #IAmHamilton spotlights Reggie Jordan, a crossing guard at CSAS. Students, parents & staff nominated Jordan for the excellent job he does and for the great welcome to school he provides children and parents every day.

“He makes every day better for my kids and me! The phrase ‘do ordinary things with extraordinary love’ reminds me of Reggie because he takes a rather tedious and potentially stressful job and turns it into a way to bless all those he encounters,” CSAS parent Liz Doescher wrote in her nomination. “He smiles big, gives high-fives, makes us laugh, and faithfully serves kids and parents with humility and kindness.”

post_text:
Hamilton County Schools will open on a two-hour delay on Friday to provide daylight for buses and drivers traveling to school tomorrow morning. The time that the bus arrives to pick up your children, the time schools open for drop-off, and the time your schools start will all be two hours later than the normal time. To find out the start time for your school, you may visit the district website. School-aged childcare locations will be open at 8:00 a.m. tomorrow morning.

The Inclement Weather Team will once again be out early in the morning checking potential trouble spots, and district personnel will work with emergency personnel to assess road conditions before buses begin their routes in case additional changes are needed in the school schedule. If changes are needed, we will make the announcement by 7 a.m.

Thank you for your patience as we work through this season where weather is difficult to predict.

Hamilton County Schools values creating safe learning conditions to support students’ physical and emotional safety, academic growth, and strong connections with parents and the community. To support our values, we are administering student, teacher, and parent surveys that will allow the educational community to better understand the relationships between conditions for learning and academic outcomes as well as better utilize available time and resources.

The surveys are now open and will close on Friday, March 13. Students will receive the survey at school, but parents and teachers can take the survey online.

Take the survey: http://bit.ly/2UPpGDC

post_text:
Today #IAmHamilton spotlights Chris Green, a bus driver in the Hixson attendance area in the North River Learning Community. Mr. Green was nominated by a parent at Hixson Middle School for the excellent job he does making the morning a great start for children riding his bus.

“I believe there is a reason for everything and I believe that Mr. Green was meant to be my son and daughter’s bus driver,” wrote Sgt. Aaron E. Berry in his nomination. “Once in a blue moon a special person like Mr. Green comes along who knows deep down what some of these kids are going through and he has empathy and a loving heart to put a smile on a child’s face on a bad day. He can put a slight hint of laughter behind his voice and tries to make each child that climbs onto his school bus feel good about themselves.”

post_text:
A Madness So Discreet by Mindy McGinnis is the #HCSBookoftheWeek nominated by Red Bank High School. Grace Mae is already familiar with madness when family secrets and the bulge in her belly send her to an insane asylum. However, it is in the darkness that she finds a new lease on life. When a visiting doctor interested in criminal psychology recognizes Grace's brilliant mind beneath her rage, he recruits her as his assistant. Continuing to operate under the cloak of madness at crime scenes allows Grace to gather clues from bystanders who believe her less than human. Now comfortable in an ethical asylum, Grace finds friends and hope. But, gruesome nights bring Grace and the doctor into the circle of a killer who will bring her shaky sanity and the demons in her past dangerously close to the surface.

“This book grabs your attention from word one," said Courtney Brown, Red Bank High School. "Every page takes you deeper into a story that seems unbelievable, is suspenseful, and keeps you thinking until the last page.”

post_text:
Hamilton County Schools will be closed on Thursday due to flooding in the area. Heavy rains and high winds are expected tonight and tomorrow with flooding around creeks and streams that will have a major impact on getting children to school and back home again. Emergency personnel are already reporting trees down in the community. Most of the flooding concerns are in the northern part of the county.

School-aged childcare locations will be open tomorrow from 8 a.m. to 6 p.m. at Battle Elementary, Daisy Elementary, East Brainerd Elementary, East Ridge Elementary, Middle Valley Elementary, Harrison Elementary, and Red Bank Elementary.

post_text: The Oldest Student By Rita Lorraine Hubbard is the #HCSBookoftheWeek nominated by Nolan Elementary. In 1848, Mary Walker was born into slavery. At age 15, she was freed, and by age 20, she was married and had her first child. By age 68, she had worked numerous jobs, including cooking, cleaning, babysitting, and selling sandwiches to raise money for her church. At 114, she was the last remaining member of her family. And at 116, she learned to read. From Rita Lorraine Hubbard and rising star Oge More comes the inspirational story of Mary Walker, a woman whose long life spanned from the Civil War to the Civil Rights Movement, and who--with perseverance and dedication--proved that you're never too old to learn.

Come enjoy two great basketball games while also supporting your local schools! The University of Tennessee at Chattanooga is hosting a “Hamilton County Schools Day” on Saturday, Feb. 22. For every ticket fans purchase for the Basketball Doubleheader, $5 will be donated to Hamilton County Schools.

To ensure part of your ticket price is donated to the district, you must purchase the tickets online or via phone (423-425-5740) in advance of the game. Tickets purchased at the door will not be a part of the fundraiser.

We hope to see you at McKenzie Arena on Saturday, Feb. 22, cheering on the Mocs!

post_text:
The Notebook of Doom is the #HCSBookoftheWeek nominated by Candace Lowe, a librarian at Daisy Elementary School. This series is part of Scholastic's early chapter book line called Branches, which is aimed at newly independent readers. With easy-to-read text, high-interest content, fast-paced plots, and illustrations on every page, these books will boost reading confidence and stamina. Branches books help readers grow!

Alexander has just moved to a new town where he is about to uncover all sorts of monsters! He finds an old notebook with the word "DOOM" inscribed on the front cover. The Notebook of Doom, which Alexander now holds, contains top secret information about monsters! In this first book, Alexander goes up against spooky balloon goons--unique and twisted arm-waving balloon guys! This book is full of humor, engaging black-and-white illustrations, and of course... monsters!

We want to hear from you! Superintendent Dr. Bryan Johnson is hosting a series of Community Budget Meetings across the district to gather feedback from Hamilton County families, staff, and community members as we head into the 2020-2021 budget season.

In order to achieve our goal of becoming the best school district in the state of Tennessee, we need family, community and staff support every step of the way. Your input is vital to the success of Hamilton County Schools.

We hope to see you at one of this year's Community Budget Meetings! #HCSBudgetFY21

post_text:
Hamilton County Schools values creating safe learning conditions to support students’ physical and emotional safety, academic growth, and strong connections with parents and the community. To support our values, we are administering student, teacher, and parent surveys that will allow the educational community to better understand the relationships between conditions for learning and academic outcomes as well as better utilize available time and resources.

The surveys are now open and will close on Friday, March 13. Students will receive the survey at school, but parents and teachers can take the survey at the links below. We would very much appreciate your help by completing the short survey.

Teacher Survey: https://teachersurvey2020.questionpro.com
Parent Survey: https://parentsurvey2020.questionpro.com
