post_text: HCS Board Meeting 12/12/19
text: HCS Board Meeting 12/12/19

post_text:
"This is my first year teaching. I feel how everyone warned me I would feel—exhausted and overwhelmed, but I also feel excited and energized. Every day I wonder if I am doing it right. I have so many doubts and even more hopes. I saw a quote last week that said,'Teaching is feeling one minute like your brain will explode and the next minute like your heart will,' and I feel that. That juxtaposition of exhaustion and happiness, stress and silliness, all of those valleys and mountains, those are what make teaching such a fulfilling adventure for me." -Jessica Murphy, Chattanooga High Center for Creative Arts

Are you an HCS educator with a 100-word teaching story to share? Submit your story: http://bit.ly/HCSTeachingStories #HCSTeachingStories

post_text:
Christmas Tapestry is the #HCSBookoftheWeek nominated by Sue Smith, librarian at Ooltewah Elementary. When a bad leak ruins the sacristy wall in his father's church, Jonathan Jefferson Weeks thinks his family's first Christmas Eve service in Detroit will be ruined too. Luckily, he and his father find a beautiful tapestry for sale in a secondhand shop - just the thing to cover the damaged wall and give the church a festive look! But there is more to the tapestry, as they discover when an old Jewish woman who is visiting the church recognizes the lovely old cloth. The tapestry brings together an elderly couple who were separated during World War II.

"The kids love the surprise ending that reveals the true owner of the tapestry.”
text:

Luckily, he and his father find a beautiful tapestry for sale in a secondhand shop - just the thing to cover the damaged wall and give the church a festive look! But there is more to the tapestry, as they discover when an old Jewish woman who is visiting the church recognizes the lovely old cloth. The tapestry brings together an elderly couple who were separated during World War II.

"The kids love the surprise ending that reveals the true owner of the tapestry.”

post_text:
This morning we went inside Ms. Retchko’s 7th grade ELA classroom at Dalewood Middle. Students were preparing for upcoming benchmark exams with a group test prep activity. The students read the text “Call It Courage” by Armstrong Perry and answered questions as a group. Each member of the group had a specific role and had to justify their answer to Ms. Retchko. The students used their Chromebooks to input their questions and earn points to complete against the class.

Thanks to Ms. Retchko and Dalewood Middle for letting us have a peek inside your classroom! #HCSInsideMyClassroom

post_text:
"My first year of teaching, I taught both seniors and freshman. I was having a really hard time learning good classroom management with the freshman and one day my seniors could tell something was wrong. I also happened to have many basketball players in my senior class. They all jokingly said they'd teach my freshman students to respect me. I didn't take them up on it, but it really made my day that they would stick up for me." -Rachel King, Ooltewah High School

Are you an HCS educator with a 100-word teaching story to share? Submit your story: http://bit.ly/HCSTeachingStories #HCSTeachingStories

What is the price of a pair of shorts?

B. $6
C. $11
D. $22

post_text:
Heartache and Other Natural Shocks is the #HCSBookoftheWeek nominated by Renee Ziemann, a Librarian at Sale Creek Middle & High School. Heartache and Other Natural Shocks is a page-turning young-adult novel told from the alternating voices of two witty, sharp-edged teenage girls who compete for a role in the school production of Hamlet and the same local bad boy, in a game of deception, betrayal, and swordplay.

"One student told me that she didn’t like to read until she found this book," said Ziemann. "Now she is one of my biggest readers.”

post_text:
This week the #IAmHamilton video feature spotlights Aliza Smith, a junior; and Jordyn Griffith, a senior at East Hamilton Middle/High. The two represented Tennessee as the only two students in the state to attend the Inclusive Youth Leadership Summit in Chicago in September.

Aliza Smith is a Special Olympian who has participated in every sport offered at least once. Smith was a founding member and a leader in the Unified Champion School program at East Hamilton.

Jordyn Griffith is high achieving student involved in multiple school-related activities. Griffith is a Unified partner with the East Hamilton Special Olympians and has gone to almost every event in which East Hamilton students participate. She was a founding member and leader of the Unified Champion School program at the school.

post_text:
"I didn't take education very seriously in high school. I went straight to work in a production plant which respectfully started my education career. In that plant an engineer noticed that I was very inquisitive about their job and I was offered an entry position in the Engineering Design Department if I also took design classes to get more education than just on-the-job training. I applied at a local community college the same week and received my associate degree in 18 months. I decided to become a teacher and give back to the community that launched my passion in teaching/education." #HCSTeachingStories

-Jennifer Miles, M. Ed, East Hamilton Middle/High School

Are you an HCS educator with a 100-word teaching story to share? Submit your story: http://bit.ly/HCSTeachingStories

post_text:
Creepy Pair of Underwear is the #HCSBookoftheWeek nominated by Caroline Mickey, a Librarian at Alpine Crest Elementary.

Jasper Rabbit is NOT a little bunny anymore. He’s not afraid of the dark, and he’s definitely not afraid of something as silly as underwear. But when the lights go out, suddenly his new big rabbit underwear glows in the dark.

"My students love this story about Jasper Rabbit, a young rabbit who wants creepy underwear that glows in the dark," said Mickey.

post_text:
Ghost Boys is the #HCSBookoftheWeek nominated by Catherine Cox, a Librarian at Normal Park Upper School. Twelve-year-old Jerome is shot by a police officer who mistakes his toy gun for a real threat. As a ghost, he observes the devastation that’s been unleashed on his family and community in the wake of what they see as an unjust and brutal killing.

"Students are able to see the devastation faced by the community from the victim's perspective, giving them a chance to deal with this difficult topic in a powerful way,” said Cox.

post_text:
Today #IAmHamilton spotlights Paul Baker, a fifth-grade student at Thrasher Elementary. Paul has been on a mission to buy books for other elementary children. He earned over $500 to buy books and delivered them to children at Calvin Donaldson Elementary, Hardy Elementary, Orchard Knob Elementary, Woodmore Elementary, and Alpine Crest Elementary.

“Paul has organized all of the details associated with this campaign, and he simply wants kindergarten friends in our local schools to learn to love reading as much as he does,” said Fannie Moore, assistant principal at Thrasher Elementary. “We are proud to have Paul in our Thrasher family, and we would like the rest of the community to know about his giving spirit.”

Paul worked to raise the money needed to buy the books, bought the books for the children, and called the principals of all the schools he planned to take books for kindergarten children and worked out details for delivery.

post_text: Hamilton County Schools will be on a 2-hour delay today due to wintery mix of rain and flurries just coming into the area now and expected to continue through 8 a.m. The delay will allow us to get daylight for better visibility for buses and drivers, as well as better road conditions in higher elevations. Precipitation is expected to end by 8 a.m. School age childcare will open on regular schedule this morning.

District personnel have been in contact with the National Weather Service and local emergency personnel throughout the day and will continue to watch the weather closely tonight.

As of the latest update at 3:46 p.m., Hamilton County is not in the National Weather Service Winter Weather Advisory for tomorrow. If forecasts or conditions change, we will let you know as early as possible in the morning.

We have included the timeline the district uses to make early morning decisions regarding school delays or closings.

It's #MathMonday! Here's our Math Problem of the Week:

Chad’s car gets 20 miles per gallon in the city and 25 miles per gallon on the highways. Which inequality represents the number of miles that he can drive on 15 gallons of gas, where x represents the number of miles he drives in the city and y represents the number of miles he drives on the highway?

Happy #MathMonday! Given f(x) = 2x – 4 and the table for function g(x) is shown below. Which statement about the functions is true?

A. Same x -intercept but different y -intercepts.
B. Same y -intercept but different x -intercepts.
C. Same x - and y -intercepts but different slopes.
D. Same slopes but different x - and y -intercepts.

post_text:
Evermore is the #HCSBookoftheWeek nominated by Jeanne Mochel, a Librarian at Soddy Daisy High School. After a horrible accident claims the lives of her family, sixteen-year-old Ever Bloom can see people's auras, hear their thoughts, and know someone's entire life story by touching them. Going out of her way to avoid human contact to suppress her abilities, she has been branded a freak at her new high school.

“Alyson Noel is a fantastic author who knows how to write a very intriguing story," said Mochel. "Wanting to put the pieces of the puzzle together is what kept me reading.”

Happy #MathMonday! Isabel saves for a bicycle by making a deposit on Monday of every week. The function shown below gives the amount A(w) in dollars Isabel has saved after she makes the deposit for week ( w).

What is A( 8 ) , and what does it represent in this situation?

A. $120; cost of the bicycle
B. $110; cost of the bicycle
C. $120; total amount saved after deposit on week 8
D. $110; total amount saved after deposit on week 8

post_text:
Took is the #HCSBookoftheWeek nominated by Lindsay Prater, a Librarian at Soddy Elementary. Another thrilling ghost story from Mary Downing Hahn, author of ‘One for Sorrow,’ that is sure to keep you turning pages. The tale begins with a Connecticut family of four moving to a tiny rural town in West Virginia. The move wouldn't be so bad, except it is clear from the beginning that the parents didn't make the decision to move into the dilapidated farmhouse themselves. They were 'urged' to by Auntie, a truly creepy character who the locals call a 'conjure' woman.

“Students love the spookiness and ghostliness of this ghost story," said Prater.
text:

Happy #MathMonday! The graph below shows the predicted growth of an American Elm tree that is planted under ideal conditions when it is 6 feet tall.

At what average rate is the height of an American Elm expected to change under ideal conditions?

A. 2/3 feet per year
B. 3 feet per year
C. 1/3 feet per year
D. 6 feet per year
